name: Jakob Macke
tweet: We made an interactive website on which you can explore all metrics, tasks and algorithms (with more than 10k model runs...). And you can add your favourite algorithms to it, or extend it to new tasks!  We hope to inspire the community to participate in this endeavour!   6/n

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Even from this initial selection, we learned a lot:  - Choice of performance metric is critical. - Even state-of-the-art algorithms have room for improvement. - There is no algorithm to rule them all ... and much more.  Lots of exciting work to be done!   5/n

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: To make it easier to see how algorithms compare to each other (both for users and researchers proposing new ones), we developed a benchmark: We selected tasks from the literature, computed ground-truth solutions, carefully selected metrics, and an initial set of algorithms.  4/n

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: But there are sooo many approaches to choose from -- many variants of Approximate Bayesian Computation and also lots of recent approaches. Some targeting likelihoods, some ratios, some posteriors, etc... and each one works great on the examples shown in its publication  😉..  3/n

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Scientists and engineers often work with models which are specified as simulators -- easy to simulate data from these, but hard (or annoying) to compute likelihoods from them. How does one infer the parameters of such models from data?  Use simulation-based inference!  2/n

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Simulation-based inference algorithms are useful to identify parameters of simulators from data. But there are so many approaches - how do they compare?  We made a benchmark!  With @janmatthis @janfiete @dvdgbg @ppjgoncalves    https://t.co/9YmzoqsDQZ  https://t.co/v6BDFmD9bL  1/n  https://t.co/7s6rPK9jHo

tweet: @peter_melchior @dr_guangtou @KyleCranmer @MilesCranmer Yes, in general one should always use likelihoods when one has them-- having said that, we have come across at least one application in which (at least our attempt at a) likelihood-based approach (we used a VAE) improved little over SBI:  https://t.co/usJJxTuhn9.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @KyleCranmer @unsorsodicorda @MilesCranmer @heghbalz There are other methods though ('Synthetic Likelihood') in which one uses e.g. a neural net to approximate the likelihood on simulations, see e.g.  https://t.co/VxcLNTdgCC,  https://t.co/AqpXeObyBu  https://t.co/uU2Qmceq3f, or as always  https://t.co/xBavzVyfxh for an overview...

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @unsorsodicorda @KyleCranmer @MilesCranmer @heghbalz The idea is that we can not (easily) evaluate P(data|simulator parameters). Even _if_ the distribution was Gaussian, it might be hard to get its mean and covariance from the simulator.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Apologies for all the typos up there (hit tweet too early), but the basic point stands: The downward slope on the r.h.s is not supported by data, but comes exclusively from a single parameter which someone set to a non-sensical value. @CellTypist fixed it- so should the authors.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: So, while we agree the paper is carefully worded, I would not call this ‘good work’ (at least not the analysis)-- I  more appropriate model fit would have generated much less hype/fear!   https://t.co/ipMdVjCBCN

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: The R-package has a (dangerous) setting which allows span >1, but then it uses a behaviour which only makes sense for multivariate data. So, whatever it does here is unclear.   https://t.co/d4ItzVOkr5

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: What happened? Looking at the (thin) method section, we noticed the authors set the  `span’ parameter of loess to 1.5—but it should be be in the range 0 to 1 (is is the relative size of the neighbourhood used for local regression, so 1=all data)!   https://t.co/R0zAu20Xx3

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @celltypist noticed this, grabbed the data and fit loess-regression in R, using the standard settings to it: And, no drop!  https://t.co/ZkRCeVF2M7

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: If one looks at their central plot,  the data looks simply but the fit does not: the line keeps going down, but the data does not seem to support this!   https://t.co/Y93Mdi0tP9

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @Timothy0Leary @MatthiasHennig6 @neurograce @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman This is an excellent discussion, but starting to exceed at least my Twitter skills ... would be fantastic to discuss these issues, in particular “engineering” and “neuroscience” approaches to modeling complicated systems, in person some time!

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @Timothy0Leary @MatthiasHennig6 @neurograce @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman Technically, one reason why the full posterior is so much better than just the marginals: it recovers the space of al models that have the same behavior,  even if some parameters can not be identified (see suppl.fig.) Granted, it might not be always worth it or necessary ...

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @ItsNeuronal @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @scott_linderman Please do, and let us know! Often one big round R=1 works really good enough, and we only do additional rounds if needed-- but for big problems selecting these hyper-parameters is not automated yet (see our discussion of limitations...). More work/benchmarks on the way!

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman The goal of SNPE it to help rapidly iterating over candidates, and to help identify degeneracies/ unidentifabilities from inspection of the posteriors.   Will it be `enough'? Surely not. But hopefully it will be a useful tool on the way.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman 4) What we tried to do with SNPE is to make a tool to find good models more easily— which, if any, parameters make my model consistent with the data? What are the geometry and directions of sensitivity/robustness of the possible parameters?

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman I am skeptical that the `right' model will be just the one that a smart theorist comes up ‘heureka’-like in a single attempt, or that just happens to be the one that happens to come out from manual tuning/guessing (arguably the state-of-the-art in practice?)

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman 3) And yes, if your model is vastly more complex than the data, then one might end up in no-persons land where everything works.  Ideally we find the ’simplest' such model— but the question is how?

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman 2) Beyond that, I would argue that it can be useful to know all parameters that ‘work’ (so that out interpretation does not overfit). Likewise, knowing that all parameters fail can also be useful.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman 1) I would argue that a minimal requirement for any model to know whether it can, or cannot capture the phenomenon we study-- not the full data, but at least the ‘emergent phenomena’ (our ’summary feature’) Otherwise, we might really give up, any analysis of the model is futile.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman Now that the technical stuff is out of the way, onto Tims question, ‘but why’:

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman 5) Importantly: SNPE does NOT need gradients, naturally works with stochastic models and yes, simulations are completely parallel (within each round).  All of these are cool technical  features we possibly did not emphasize enough in the preprint   https://t.co/jZlI8igLo1

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman 3) We don’t need to define a hard ‘rejection criterion’ (which can be hard in high-d). 4)  If you like the Bayesian inference machinery (priors, pooling data, sequential inference, posteriors) you can have it all.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman 2) From the inferred posterior, we can e.g. compute paths between solutions, directions of sensitivity and robustness, conditional posteriors to explore local parameter sensitives without ANY extra simulations (e.g. Fig 5 C and 6).

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman 1) Scaling:  Using slightly fewer simulations, we can scale to >30 parameters (infeasible with grid-search), and also much better than ABC methods.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @neurograce @Timothy0Leary @ItsNeuronal @scott_linderman ll, thanks for the excellent thoughts, Ill try to catch up,  Thread coming:  ‘Brute Force’: Yes, SNPE requires many simulations (see methods), but has several advantages over the seminal Prinz et al papers (which I love of course ...):  (Thread)

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Cool, useful aside. Yes, Bayesian inference is slow, as are simulations. But here we can amortize inference, i.e. we 'store' it in the neural net. On new data, we can just use the network again, which is lightning-fast. One could do full Bayesian inference in real time! (8/n)  https://t.co/8Yynv8Bc7y

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Outputs of High-posterior (i.e. 'good') models (purple)  look like the input-data (green), output from low-posterior ('bad') models  (pink) do not: (7/n)  https://t.co/pi9EBrpR3P

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: We run this on multiple examples: Exhibit 1: Ion-channel models (with @TPVogels et al). The approach finds the posterior (read: space of params that work) (6/n)  https://t.co/txlzPPvyS1

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: This only requires a way to simulate data, not access to the internals of the model. So, we can also use it on messy, non-differentiable, custom-coded models, and we can use it to find models that target summary statistics ('give me all networks with correlation 0.1') (5/n)

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Basic idea: Generate lots of synthetic data from model simulations with random params. Then train a neural net on this data, and if you do it right [insert: lots of technical details] it learns to do inference. We call this Sequential Neural Posterior Estimation (SNPE). (4/n)  https://t.co/Ug4W6YEA7G

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Wouldn't it be great to have inference tools that work for these models? Then we could build the models we want, AND do statistical inference to explore the space of parameters that captures data.  This is what we did here, using shiny ML tools (simulation-based inference). (3/n)

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: Models in neuro are ideally built on our assumptions about underlying mechanisms, often using classical theories (Hodgkin Huxley, E/I Balance, ..). Catch is: Getting models and data to agree can be tricky, and people spend time tuning parameters by hand or with heuristics. (2/n)

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @andpru @EricMTrautmann @xaqlab @KriegeskorteLab @GunnarBlohm @KordingLab @kjosic @northernthrux @BMI_WesternU Providers of great data can  get a large number of data-authorships, which hopefully is more credit than 'just' soft community recognition + citations.  (Of course, if a 'data-author' is fully involved in a study, he/she is instead is a standard author.)

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @andpru @EricMTrautmann @xaqlab @KriegeskorteLab @GunnarBlohm @KordingLab @kjosic @northernthrux @BMI_WesternU Importantly, he/she does not need to be involved in the study and analyses itself, or even share its conclusions and findings. The ‘academic market’ will assign a value to a data-authorship- less valuable than  ‘real’ authorship, but substantially more valuable than a citation.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @andpru @EricMTrautmann @xaqlab @KriegeskorteLab @GunnarBlohm @KordingLab @kjosic @northernthrux @BMI_WesternU Alright, an idea about incentivizing successful data-sharing  that I have been going on about for a while: Introduce new authorship category called ‘data-author’. name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @aexbrown @NatureComms There are probably others (e.g. the triggered-covariance approaches mentioned by @wbialek). I think the paper would really have benefited from discussing the relationships of these approaches, and reporting empirical comparisons.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @aexbrown @NatureComms I can easily think of at least two: a) Demixed PCA,  https://t.co/Egi5SvSjY0, which seems to be the same algorithm when alpha=1, and b) Oriented PCA, (Diamantaras and Kung, 1996) which uses the Rayleigh-Quotient, rather than the difference of covariances.

name: Jakob Macke
tweet: @aexbrown This looks like a neat paper, kudos for nice code and visuals, and to @NatureComms for publishing methods. However, I am surprised by the claim that "But no [dimensionality reduction methods] are designed to utilize relevant information from a second dataset, as cPCA does.”
